;;欧盟委员 Věra Jourová
;

;欧盟已向埃隆·马斯克发出警告，要求其遵守继 X（前身为 Twitter）被发现在所有大型社交媒体平台上发布虚假信息帖子比例最高之后，针对假新闻和俄罗斯宣传的全面新法律也出台了。

;

;据报道，Facebook 是第二严重违规者。根据 8 月生效的《数字服务法案》(DSA)，有史以来第一份在整个欧盟范围内记录帖子将被视为非法的报告。

;

;然而，Facebook 和其他科技巨头，包括谷歌、TikTok和微软已经签署了欧盟制定的行为准则，以确保他们能够及时做好在新法律范围内运营的准备。

;

;Twitter 保留了行为准则，但它有义务欧盟委员维拉·朱罗瓦 (Věra Jourová) 表示：“马斯克先生知道，他并不能因为放弃行为准则而摆脱困境。”负责实施新的反虚假信息守则。

;

;“硬法规定了义务。所以我给 Twitter/X 的信息是你必须遵守。我们会关注你们的行为。”

;

;这份 200 页的报告记录了大型平台在 2023 年前六个月为遵守新法律所做的准备工作，并提升了掩盖 Facebook 和其他公司为打击俄罗斯宣传、仇恨言论和其他虚假信息所做的幕后努力。

;

;“俄罗斯国家参与了思想战，污染了我们的信息空间Jourová 表示：“用半真半假的谎言来制造民主并不比专制更好的虚假形象。”

;

;Google 旗下的 YouTube 告诉欧盟，它已经删除了“400 多个涉及协调影响力的频道”。报告称，谷歌还删除了近 300 个与“国家资助的宣传网站”相关的网站上的广告。

;

;Meta ，将其事实核查范围扩大到涵盖欧盟 22 种语言的 26 个合作伙伴，目前还包括捷克语和斯洛伐克语。

;

;欧盟特别担心俄罗斯在周日和斯洛伐克举行关键选举之前在社交媒体上持续进行的宣传。 10 月 15 日在波兰。

;

;TikTok 最近因 ;违反有关儿童的数据保护规则;，也正在努力遵守 DSA。

;

;其事实核查涵盖俄语、乌克兰语和其他 17 种语言，并与路透社建立了新的合作伙伴关系。

;

;报告称，通过该网络检查了 832 个与乌克兰战争相关的视频，其中 211 个被删除。< /p>;

;该行为准则的另一家参与者微软告诉欧盟，它已经对有关乌克兰战争的 800,000 个搜索查询的可疑信息进行了升级或降级。

;

;Jourová 表示报告证明俄罗斯正在进行一场“思想战”，克里姆林宫的虚假信息在大型平台上仍然非常普遍。

;

;她说，克里姆林宫选择斯洛伐克而不是波兰作为发展的“沃土”分裂和对民主的干扰。

;

;她说，她向大型平台传达的主要信息之一是要了解选举，包括明年欧洲议会的选举，以及“虚假信息的风险”。

; Tue, 26 Sep 2023 18:52:01 +0800 Europe’s banks helped fossil fuel firms raise more than €1tn from global bond marketshttps://www.theguardian.com/business/2023/sep/26/europes-banks-helped-fossil-fuel-firms-raise-more-than-1tn-from-global-bond-markets

;;俄罗斯石油公司 (Rosneft) 拥有的俄罗斯 Vankor 油气田的塔楼中燃烧着火焰
;

;根据《卫报》及其报告合作伙伴的一项调查，自巴黎气候协议签订以来，包括欧洲一些最大的银行在内的银行已帮助化石燃料公司从全球债券市场筹集了超过 1 万亿欧元（8,690 亿英镑）。

;

;在推动零碳排放的过程中，欧洲最大的贷款机构面临着越来越大的压力，要求限制通过直接贷款和其他融资设施对化石燃料公司的财务支持。

;

;但是对 2016 年以来的数千笔交易进行了分析，当时更多190多个国家在巴黎举行的联合国峰会上同意通过遏制污染来限制全球变暖，据透露，德意志银行、汇丰银行和巴克莱银行等银行通过支持销售化石燃料债券，继续从石油、天然气和煤炭的扩张中获利.

;

;调查结果引起了可持续投资活动人士的担忧，即银行继续向负责增加世界碳排放的能源公司提供“隐性”财务支持，尽管它们公开承诺逐步淘汰直接投资

;

;《卫报》与其他欧洲报纸以及荷兰平台 Investico 和 Follow the Money 合作，详细研究了金融信息提供商彭博社记录的 1,700 笔债券发行情况。

;

;公司发行债券是为了帮助为特定项目或其一般运营筹集资金。它们实际上充当公司与购买债券的投资者之间的借据。银行通过向客户和其他投资者承销和营销债券以及提供咨询或管理服务来赚取费用。承销银行通过在全球债券市场上将债券出售给投资者之前购买债券来保证债券销售。通常，单次债券发行将涉及多家银行的帮助。

;

;调查仅关注活动组织 Urgewald 确定的能源公司的债券，这些公司公开披露了增加化石燃料产量的目标，以及自《巴黎气候协定》签署以来。该协议的目标是将气温上升限制在比工业化前水平高出 2 摄氏度的范围内。气候专家警告说，没有任何新的化石燃料项目符合《巴黎协定》。

;

;研究显示，自 2016 年初以来，通过全球债券市场发行的此类债券已达 1 万亿欧元。大借款人包括巴西国家政府拥有石油公司巴西国家石油公司和俄罗斯国家石油公司俄罗斯石油公司。巴黎协议承诺全球各国政府采取行动。

;

;研究显示，欧洲化石燃料债券的主要推动者是德国德意志银行、英国汇丰银行和巴克莱银行，以及法国农业信贷银行和法国巴黎银行。

; ;

;随着欧洲金融中心采取气候兼容政策的压力越来越大，许多银行已经放弃了与大型化石燃料的传统贷款关系据活动人士称，公司通过帮助发行公司债券来获得更间接的支持。

;

;大多数银行在衡量其在气候变化方面的表现时，选择不计算其受薪的债券销售量，即使筹集了资金在支持一些最大排放国的新高碳项目方面发挥着重要作用。

;

;气候专家，包括哥本哈根商学院可持续发展中心的商业与社会教授安德烈亚斯·拉斯切（Andreas Rasche）批评银行未能承担起帮助化石燃料公司通过债券市场获得资金的责任。

;

;Rasche 表示：“参与承销活动使银行成为石油和天然气公司发行债券所产生排放的同谋” 。你帮助他们筹集资金，并且你知道这些钱将用来做什么——因此你参与了这项活动。”

;

;活动人士表示，全球债券市场已成为大型污染企业的“后门”在对直接银行融资的审查日益严格的情况下，他们计划为其项目获得融资。

;

;“我们不能再忽视债券市场了，”气候运动组织 Sunrise Project 的策略师 Alice Delemare Tangpuori 表示。 “银行的作用相当隐蔽。但他们本质上是这些债券的啦啦队长。”

;

;“化石燃料公司实际上正在利用债券作为筹集资金的后门，”Delemare Tangpuori 表示。 “这些公司现在正在转向债券市场筹集资金。这些银行非常乐意帮助他们做到这一点。对于那些希望为化石燃料公司撤资的人来说，进入债券市场是致命的开关。”

;

;Reclaim Finance 的可持续投资活动家 Lara Cuvelier 表示：“这是他们继续与这些公司合作的一种方式。公司，以保持商业联系。帮助这些公司在债券市场筹集资金表明他们不愿意打破这些联系并停止支持化石燃料公司。”

;

;“他们帮助这些公司获得的新资金与他们的承诺不符。到 2050 年实现净零排放。”Cuvelier 补充道。 “这项调查清楚地表明，银行以及投资者迫切需要采取涵盖所有金融服务（包括债券）的特定行业政策。”

;

;根据研究，德意志银行是最大的银行，作为自巴黎气候协议签署以来，化石燃料债券的承销商或账簿管理人筹集了总计 4,320 亿欧元的资金。与此同时，该银行承诺到 2030 年将石油和天然气行业的“融资排放”减少 23%，到 2050 年减少 90%。

; ;

;该银行在一份声明中表示，“自 2016 年以来，特别是去年，已大幅减少了与石油和天然气行业的合作”。它补充说，德意志银行“根本无意将业务范围从贷款转向为化石燃料行业客户发行债券”。

;

;研究发现，英国汇丰银行为债券提供了便利，从而筹集了资金自 2016 年以来，为化石燃料公司提供了 4230 亿欧元的资金，同时承诺到本世纪末将石油和天然气行业的融资排放量减少 34%，到 2050 年实现净零排放。

;

;汇丰银行没有对此做出回应

;

;与此同时，法国农业信贷银行和法国巴黎银行帮助发行债券，根据调查，分别筹集了 3510 亿欧元和 2950 亿欧元。法国农业信贷银行承诺到 2050 年将其融资排放量减少到零。法国巴黎银行今年早些时候表示，将停止对新化石燃料项目的所有融资，但该政策仍然允许该银行为化石燃料公司本身提供融资。

;

;法国巴黎银行发言人表示，调查的历史范围并不反映该银行最近在“扭转化石燃料问题”方面取得的进展。该银行声称，其在石油和天然气公司债券市场的份额到 2023 年已降至 0.99%，而 2020 年的市场份额为 3.39%。

;

;法国农业信贷银行表示，该决定不包括在石油和天然气公司的债券安排。其气候目标符合 2021 年在格拉斯哥举行的第 26 届联合国气候变化大会期间银行联盟采用的方法。“但是，一旦投资者持有债券，就会将其纳入其投资发行中，”银行发言人表示。

;

;总部位于伦敦的巴克莱银行是少数几家将其资本市场活动纳入其到 2050 年成为净零银行的雄心的银行之一。该银行帮助化石燃料公司筹集了价值 3500 亿欧元的债券研究显示，自《巴黎协定》签署以来的几年内。

;

;巴克莱银行发言人表示，该银行于 2020 年制定的气候目标不仅涵盖其直接贷款，还涵盖其促进的资本市场融资，比如发行债券。该发言人表示：“我们是最早这样做的银行之一。”调查发现，墨西哥国有石油公司 Petroleos Mexicanos 自成立以来筹集了 1150 亿欧元，成为化石燃料债券的最大受益者。 2016 年。同期，巴西石油公司筹集了 380 亿欧元，而俄罗斯石油公司筹集了 340 亿欧元。壳牌和英国石油公司分别通过化石燃料债券筹集了 310 亿欧元和 290 亿欧元。

;;西班牙人民党领袖阿尔贝托·努涅斯·费霍本周在马德里与支持者在一起。
;

;两个月;赢得 7 月大选后，但由于未能获得绝对多数;，西班牙保守派人民党 (PP) 的领导人正在发起几乎注定注定失败的竞选，以成为该国下一任首相。

;

;尽管阿尔贝托领导的人民党努涅斯·费霍在提前选举中名列第一，但未能赢得足够的选票来组建政府，在西班牙国会 350 个席位中占据了 137 个席位。尽管存在计算上的挑战，费利佩国王还是要求该党在本周的授职会议上尝试组建政府，该会议将从周二的一天辩论开始。

;

;

;人民党抓住了大赦的可能性来争取支持，并将这位西班牙社会工人党领导人描绘成懦弱的人，依赖加泰罗尼亚分离主义者，一意孤行。留任。在他的政党的;大型、反-周日在马德里举行的特赦抗议;中，费乔指责桑切斯“完全缺乏道德和政治诚信”，并为了保住首相职位而贬低了西班牙民主。

;

;但是桑切斯一直小心翼翼地避免明确提及特赦。国际特赦组织有信心他能够吸引到留在蒙克洛亚宫所需的 176 票。 “[人民党]正在示威反对社会主义政府，”他周日在加泰罗尼亚告诉支持者。 “但是我很抱歉——将会有一个社会主义政府。”

;在地方检察官办公室请求帮助后，齐罗贾尼斯表示，他提供了证据并对涉及希腊神话人物卡斯托尔和波勒克斯雕像的案件进行分析。他能够分享重要证据（照片和文件），证明这些四世纪的大理石雕塑是从黎巴嫩被掠夺的，正如他在论文研究中发现的那样。

; ;

;Tsirogiannis 表示，他在与该单位表示，他提供的论文信息受到限制，并且他发送这些信息的前提是他将获得学分。他说，该部门回复他表示感谢，并要求提供更多详细信息，他也提供了这些信息。

;

;他说，他惊讶地发现，当曼哈顿地方检察官办公室 ;本月早些时候宣布将雕像归还黎巴嫩;。;

;“这真是太可耻了。我大声疾呼是为了保护我的同事，提醒他们他们的知识产权将被滥用。”

;

;“人们期望至少有礼貌，尤其是来自那些自称帮助伸张正义的人。”他说。

;

;虽然 Tsirogiannis 居住在剑桥，是该大学的特邀考古学讲师，但他却是非法古物贩运研究的负责人担任希腊科孚岛爱奥尼亚大学联合国教科文组织文化遗产威胁主席。

;

;在过去 17 年里，他在拍卖行、画廊、博物馆和私人收藏中识别出了 1,600 多件被掠夺的文物，通知国际刑警组织和其他警察部队。

;
;;A brown bear cub and its mother on the Shiretoko Peninsula in Japan in 2015
;

;As many as eight in 10 brown bear cubs born this year in a remote part of northern Japan have died amid a shortage of salmon, with experts blaming rising sea temperatures caused by the ;climate crisis;.

;

;Along with acorns, pink salmon are an important source of food for the estimated 500 brown bears living along Hokkaido's < a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2008/may/28/climatechange.conservation">;Shiretoko peninsula;, a Unesco world heritage site known for its dramatic coastline and wild animals.;

;Local officials reacted with alarm after a tour boat operator spotted a starving bear cub desperately searching for food on the peninsula's eastern coat this month. The bear was reportedly turning over rocks and rummaging through piles of beached seaweed in search of food.

;

;Pink salmon that hatch in rivers in Hokkaido spend the winter in the sea, before returning to streams in Shiretoko between August and October to lay eggs. Brown bears typically lie in wait for the salmon as they make their way upstream, but have been forced to swim in the sea because of the shortage of river fish.

;

;“Some bears have grown really thin,” Katsuya Noda, the tour boat operator, told the Asahi Shimbun. “They are having a tough time, because there are no fish in the rivers, just like last year.”

;

;Experts said sea surface temperatures off Hokkaido remained above 20C from mid-July to early August 2021, 5C higher than average for that time of the year.

;

;Researchers at Hokkaido University have warned that if global heating continues at its current rate, seawater temperature around the island will rise by up to 10C in the 2090s compared with 1980s levels.

;

;Masami Yamanaka, a researcher at the Shiretoko Nature Foundation, told the Asahi that the lack of salmon, combined with a poor acorn harvest, was having a devastating effect on brown bear cubs. “An estimated 70% to 80% of the cubs born this year are dead,” Yamanaka said. “It's a really serious situation.”

;

;Fishers caught 482,775 pink salmon in rivers in Hokkaido, Japan's northernmost main island, between 25 July and 5 September in 2020, but only 23,298 last year, according to the Hokkaido Salmon Propagation Association. Given statistical evidence showing that good catches occur every other year, the 2022 haul was surprisingly small.

;

;The scarcity of acorns has been blamed for a rise in the number of ;bear attacks; on humans in Hokkaido and other parts of northern ;Japan,; as they venture into populated areas in search of food.

;

;A total of 1,056 brown bears were caught and killed in Hokkaido in the year up to April 2022 – the highest figure on record and the first time the number has exceeded 1,000, according to the prefecture's government. Of the total, 999 brown bears were exterminated to prevent damage to crops or because they were considered a danger to local people.

;

;The number of people injured or killed in incidents involving bears totaled 14 in the same period, with crop damage estimated at ¥262m (£1.44m) – both the highest figures on record.

;;President Emmerson Mnangagwa announces his new cabinet at the State House in Harare
;

;Barely a week after being sworn in as an opposition MP ;following elections in Zimbabwe last month;, Gift Siziba found himself in policy custody facing several charges, including inciting violence at a football match and defacing posters of an opponent in Bulawayo.

;

;While other legislators debate in parliament, Siziba, from the Citizens Coalition for Change (CCC), has been in and out of court defending his innocence.

;

;Siziba is just one of a number of opposition politicians and activists who have been arrested and charged with various offences since President Emmerson Mnangagwa won a second term in the 23 August vote, a result the CCC described as a “gigantic fraud”.

;

;Others have faced a worse fate.

;

;Womberaishe Nhende, a newly elected local councillor from a Harare suburb, was allegedly abducted, tortured and dumped naked near a river earlier this month, according to rights groups.

;

;His lawyers say Nhende and an unnamed relative were also injected with an unknown substance during the brief disappearance. Nhende is reported to have fled the country since the attack.

;

;Nhende's lawyer, Doug Coltart, was also detained then freed on bail. Coltart described the two developments as “a worrying indication of the state of the rule of law in Zimbabwe and the direction that this regime is going in the five years ahead”.

;

;The Opposition MP Maureen Kademaunga spent a night in police cells having been charged with attempted murder and malicious damage to property, only to be cleared of wrongdoing after prosecutors failed to present evidence in court.

;

;And Kudzai Kadzombe, a CCC politician and deputy mayor in Harare, was arrested for allegedly assaulting a member of the ruling Zanu-PF party before the election. She is out on bail.

;

;The CCC says the cases have brought to intimidate it after last month's disputed election. “Public officials, supporters, civilians are being targeted on account of who they voted for in the last election. The regime is targeting all the voices of dissent,” Siziba told the Guardian. “It is a clear confirmation that the regime did not win the election. There was no victory for them, that is why they are turning against their own citizens.”

;

;The crackdown has also drawn criticism from rights groups.

;

;“We are concerned about the crackdown that we continue to see in the aftermath of the elections,” said Wilbert Mandinde, the acting executive director of the Zimbabwe Human Rights NGO Forum, a coalition of civil society organisations.

;

;“Whilst we do not condone some acts of a criminal nature, we continue to be shocked about some of these arrests. We believe they [the authorities] are bent on trying to make things difficult for the opposition.”

;

;Promise Mkananzi, a CCC spokesperson, is in self-imposed exile after a 2020 arrest warrant against him for “defaulting court proceedings” resurfaced. The case, which he said had been resolved, related to alleged incitement of public violence.

;

;He accused Zanu-PF of orchestrating the jailing of opposition MPs in an attempt to restore its two-thirds parliamentary majority.

;

;“The post-election crackdown is clear evidence of anger, vindictiveness and bitterness,” he said. “It is also a protracted effort to restore their parliamentary majority by hook or crook.” Mkwananzi claimed Zanu-PF was seeking a two thirds majority in part so that Mnangagwa could change the constitution to allow him to seek a third term.

;

;In last month's election, neither of the two main parties secured a two-thirds majority, meaning no wholesale changes can be made to the constitution, including amending the presidential term limits.

;

;Critics have long accused Zanu-PF – in power since independence in 1980 – of using the courts to target opposition politicians and silence dissent.

;

;A police spokesperson, Paul Nyathi, denied authorities were targeting the CCC, saying they were “simply following protocols” by responding to reports of wrongdoing.

;

;“If we don't arrest suspects after matters have been reported, the public will complain that we are sleeping on the job. So as the police, we are doing our job,” he told Agence France-Presse last week.

;

;Mnangagwa, 81, won a second term with 52.6% of the vote, against 44% for CCC leader Nelson Chamisa, 45, according to official results. Chamisa maintains the election was stolen and has called for a fresh vote, as well as urging the Southern African Development Community (SADC) to intervene.

;

;International observers, including from the SADC, a regional bloc that usually endorses polls in member countries, said the election fell short of democratic standards.

;

;Mnangagwa promised to uphold the rule of law during his inauguration speech. “Under my leadership and the new Zanu PF government,” Mnangagwa said, “democracy, good governance, the rule of law and the politics of tolerance will be entrenched, in line with the spirit and letter of our sacred national constitution and laws.”

; Tue, 26 Sep 2023 15:52:01 +0800 Thai pro-democracy activist jailed for speaking out at monarchy protesthttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/sep/26/thai-pro-democracy-activist-arnon-nampa-jailed-monarchy-protest
;;2023-09-26T06:54:39Z;
;
;;Arnon Nampa talks to reporters outside court in Bangkok, Thailand
;

;A prominent pro-democracy activist has been sentenced to four years in prison for a speech he delivered during protests calling for reform of Thailand's powerful monarchy.

;

;Arnon Nampa, a human rights lawyer, was at the forefront of a protest movement that erupted in 2020, when hundreds of thousands of people, many of them young students, took to the streets to call for democratic changes, including to the role of monarchy.

;

;The protests led to unprecedented, open discussion of the behaviour and status of the royal family – a topic that had previously been considered off limits for public debate.

;

;The monarchy is shielded from criticism by a strict lese-majesty law, under which any perceived insult of the royals can lead to a prison sentence of up to 15 years.

;

;Since the 2020 protests, which had called for the law to be scrapped, it has been used against at least 257 people, including children, according to Thai Lawyers for Human Rights. Protesters have been accused under the law for a variety of alleged offences – from ;wearing fancy dress; and ;crop tops; deemed an insult to the monarchy, for social media posts and distributing ;satirical cartoons;.

;

;The sentence handed down to Arnon on Tuesday is the first of 14 lese-majesty cases he faces. He is requesting bail while he appeals against the court's decision.
;
; As he arrived at court on Tuesday, Arnon told Reuters he had no regrets for what was “a worthwhile personal sacrifice for the greater good”.

;

;“The youth protest has created a phenomenon that has changed Thailand to the point of no return,” he said. “I believe that the people are becoming more confident in their freedom and equality and are ready to transform the country to be more progressive.”

;

;The case against Arnon relates to a speech he delivered on 14 October 2020, according to a summary published by Thai Lawyers for Human Rights. During the speech, he called for monarchy reform, and told crowds that if there was any order to crack down on protesters that day, this would have come only from the king.

;

;The prosecutor said that the comment damaged the king's reputation, according to TLHR.

;

;Arnon was sentenced to four years in prison and fined 20,000 baht (£453.32) over the speech. He had denied it was his intention to defame the king, and said his comment was aimed only at preventing a police crackdown on protesters.

;

;Thailand's lese-majesty law has been criticised by international rights groups and ;UN experts;.

;

;The progressive Move Forward party, which won the most seats and votes in this year's election, had pledged to change the law. However, it was ;blocked from taking power; by unelected, military-appointed senators, who fiercely oppose any efforts to weaken lese-majesty and who view the monarchy as a key pillar of Thai society that must be protected.

;

;Move Forward and its former leader Pita Limjaroenrat face a legal case over their campaign pledge to amend the law, after it was alleged that such a policy amounted to an attempt “to overthrow the democratic regime of government with the king as a head of state”.

;
;;A crowd outside a French army base at night in Niamey
;

;Aides and supporters of Niger's ;deposed president, Mohamed Bazoum;, have welcomed the decision of France to withdraw its diplomatic staff and military from the country, saying it will deny the military junta a “scapegoat” to disguise its failings.

;

;Bazoum, a French ally whose election in 2021 had boosted hopes of stability in the unstable Sahel state, was ;detained on 26 July by members of his guard;. Senior soldiers took power in the unstable Sahel state shortly afterwards.

;

;Relations with France, the country's former colonial power and former ally in its fight against jihadism, went swiftly downhill after Paris stood by Bazoum who has remained confined in the presidential palace with his wife and son since the coup.

;

;President Emmanuel Macron told French viewers during a televised address on Sunday that military cooperation with Niger was “over” and that ;French troops would withdraw by the end of the year;.

;
;

;;Related: ;;France to withdraw ambassador and troops from Niger;

;
;

;“France has decided to withdraw its ambassador,” Macron told French television. “In the next hours our ambassador and several diplomats will return to France.”

;

;The announcement appeared to end two months of defiance in which Paris's ambassador had been kept in place in Niamey despite coup leaders ordering him to leave.

;

;Macron added that military cooperation was over and French troops would withdraw in “the months and weeks to come”.

;

;About 1,500 French troops have been stationed in Niger as part of a broader campaign against Islamic extremist militants across the Sahel region, but were recently reinforced when Paris was forced to redeploy forces from Mali after ;a military coup there;.

;

;A ;third coup; also forced Paris to withdraw forces from Burkina Faso, another former French colony. There and in Mali, French officials have pointed to a flood of Russian propaganda as a significant destabilising force. The Kremlin has been making a big push to expand its influence and presence in sub-Saharan Africa, often at the expense of France.

;

;Social media channels associated with the Russian state in August launched ;a major effort to exploit the coup in Niger;, possibly seeking to open opportunities for intervention.

;

;In his address, Macron insisted that French troops were “not [in the Sahel] to be held hostages by putschists” who he described as “friends of chaos”.

;

;Analysts have described a near disaster for French policy in the Sahel.

;

;Jean-Hervé Jezequel, director of the Sahel Project at International Crisis Group, said events in Niger marked “the beginning of the end of a sequence of French troops withdrawing from the central Sahel.

;

;“It is a failure of their intervention whatever the French say. They did not stop the progress of the jihadists and they have ruined their relationship with three former colonies. It's not a full-scale disaster for the French but very close to that,” Jezequel said.

;

;After weeks of rallies against France, Macron's announcement provoked apparently ;spontaneous celebrations in Niamey;, the capital. On social media, users in Niger posted now familiar accusations that France had supported extremist groups to allow interventions designed to secure Niger's uranium, and welcomed a victory over “neo-imperialism”.

;

;Niger's military leaders welcomed the French decision.

;

;“Today we celebrate a new era … It is a historic moment which demonstrates the determination and will of the people of Niger … Neo-imperialist and colonial forces are not welcome in the territory of Niger,” they said in a statement.

;

;France has not recognised the authority of Niger's military leaders and is still demanding the restoration of Bazoum.

;

;Andrew Lebovich, an expert on Niger at The Hague-based Clingendael Institute, said that the new military rulers had been able to exploit deep popular animosity towards France.

;

;“The very significant degree of distrust of France was really underestimated [in Paris]. There's a tendency to ascribe all of this to Russian disinformation and propaganda but, though that's a factor, the French have had real difficulty understanding why Russian propaganda is landing on such fertile ground,” Lebovich said.

;

;Niger is a key base for western troops in the Sahel and has for years battled against its own armed jihadist groups.

;

;Attacks have continued since the coup, such as on 15 August when 17 Nigerien soldiers were killed.

;

;Inhabitants of cities like Niamey and major towns have been hit by blackouts and soaring prices for basics since the coup.

;

;“Now that France is on its way out the [regime] will have to learn to protect populations. The putchsts won't have any scapegoat and will have to face the reality,” said Mohamed Abdelder, an adviser of Bazoum.

;

;A second adviser of the deposed president said that the population of Niger would have to realise that “populism has its limits”.

;

;“France was the only selling point of the junta, attracting all the attention and hiding all its internal contradictions. In withdrawing, France takes away the main propaganda argument of the junta. It's a pragmatic and strategic decision … an act of responsibility and political clarity,” the adviser said.

;

;The regional organisation Ecowas has imposed sanctions and threatened military intervention to restore Bazoum, though few believe this is likely to occur.

;

;Jezequel said the junta included many senior officials and soldiers associated with unpopular former governments who had used anti-French sentiment to “reinvent themselves as newcomers”.

;

;“The question is what next? Who is your scapegoat now you have kicked out France?,” he said. “For Sahel countries [like Niger, Mali and Burkina Faso] prospects are pretty gloomy.”

;

;Niger's new leaders, who justified their power grab by the deteriorating security situation and high level of corruption and say they intend to try Bazoum for “high treason”, on Thursday listed 20 members of his government as wanted.

;

;Bazoum's lawyer has called on an Ecowas court to free the former president in the name of “arbitrary arrest”, “violation of freedom of movement” and to restore constitutional order.
